Cell-s1jgw6rh-0 hmnTYZ" id="main-column"><p class="fqygwe-0-Paragraph-hHEPzZ kSikFP" size="3" spacing="5"><span class="s14xcvr1-0-Raw-dZnnZd bRyDXB" fontcolor="#333333" size="3" spacing="0">A view of s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP juwgkm"><span class="aabx0k-0-Span-juOiwt ldywyG" color="#666666" size="2"><svg role="img" class="s1sojkux-0-Icon-cxuQhR jnxwvW" rotate="0" fill="#666666"><filter id="dropshadow" filter="0"></use></svg>(Bonnie Jo Mount/The Washington Post/Getty Images)</span></span></p><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP jxkEdK" id="ad-in-text-target"><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p><span class="lede">SEATTLE — That </span><a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/washington">Washington</a> state boasts a booming economy is hardly a shock. The state is home to Amazon.com, after all, and a mature tech sector led by Microsoft. Washington apples, wheat, hops and grapes feed and inebriate the world. Boeing Co. aircraft circle it. </p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>But Washington has a supercharger: power.</p></div><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP gYDkWa" spacing="4">[ <p class="AnchorBlock__KickerLine-ebdzwh-0 kGSXVo sc-bxivhb hgrABU" size="2" spacing="3" weight="7"><span class="Kicker__KickerSpan-s930mv6-0 dsOAje">MORE:  </span></p><a class="Anchor-u1fur6-0 bRRClC" href="//www.usnews.com/news/best-states" letter-spacing="0.6" prefix="\00ab\00a0">The 2019 Best States Ranking</a> ]</div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Cheap, climate-friendly electricity drives Washington's economy, the nation's fastest growing, according to the U.S. News' Best States ranking of <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/rankings/economy/growth">economic growth</a>. The tech-heavy state's expectedly strong broadband network sits atop one of the nation's best electrical systems, one well-positioned as the country shifts away from coal- and natural gas-generated electricity. The state expects to be coal-free by 2025, while still charging rates among the nation's lowest.</p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 gHribn s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP jMIcnN" spacing="5" style=""><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 goJCnX Box-s85n6m5-0 bWNXcr" spacing="4"><div id="ad" class="ad lazy " data-ad-type="inart" data-dimensions="1x1,fluid" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Aging hydroelectric dams provide most of the electricity Washington uses or exports, but windmills and solar arrays are increasingly common sights on the arid rolling hills east of the Cascade Mountains. Gov. Jay Inslee, the state's <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2019-04-17/for-jay-inslee-a-methodical-buildup-to-a-long-2020-campaign"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">leading clean energy evangelist-turned-presidential hopeful</u></a>, describes those projects as doubly fruitful: Customers get clean energy, and rural residents get <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/rankings/opportunity/economic-opportunity">economic opportunity</a>.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"Washington state is an example of how climate action and a strong economy go hand in hand," Inslee told U.S. News & World Report. </p></div><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP iBesDW" spacing="5"><div class="Box-s85n6m5-0 byiZm" spacing="5"><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP hQAyvA"><h3 class="sc-bdVaJa hcneNz" size="3" sizelarge="5" spacing="0" weight="7">Browse Photos of the 50 States</h3></div><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP gtRwrM"><picture class="Image__Picture-afx55j-0 eVypoR"><img style="height: 493.922px; width: 752.656px; background: #000"></picture><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP iQVKPy"><button class="s1gfvgx7-0-Button-kDSBcD LobbB" background="white" border="#aaaaaa"><div class="button-content"><svg role="img" class="s1sojkux-0-Icon-cxuQhR eJDnbY" rotate="0" fill="#ffffff"><filter id="dropshadow" x="15%" y="20%" height="80%" width="80%"><feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="2"></feGaussianBlur><feOffset dx="2" dy="1" result="offsetblur"></feOffset><feComponentTransfer><feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.25"></feFuncA></feComponentTransfer><feMerge><feMergeNode></feMergeNode><feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"></feMergeNode></feMerge></filter><use xlink:href="#image" filter="0"></use></svg>View All 51 Images</div></button></div><div class="SlideshowEmbed__ArrowWrapper-s17irtfo-0 cmGvZX"><button class="Arrows__Button-s2llb5h-0 gKQSmy"><svg role="img" class="Icon-s1sojkux-0 bnJYCx" rotate="-90" fill="white"><filter id="dropshadow" x="15%" y="20%" height="80%" width="80%"><feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="2"></feGaussianBlur><feOffset dx="2" dy="1" result="offsetblur"></feOffset><feComponentTransfer><feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.25"></feFuncA></feComponentTransfer><feMerge><feMergeNode></feMergeNode><feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"></feMergeNode></feMerge></filter><use xlink:href="#chevron" filter="0"></use></svg></button></div></div></div></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"Renewable energy projects create significant new revenues for rural communities where most of these projects are sited," said the governor, whose bid for the Democratic presidential nomination centers on climate change. "New wind development projects in Washington generate millions of dollars in annual lease payments; much of it goes to small rural landowners."</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p><b>A Tech-Sector Powerhouse</b></p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 gHribn s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP cApUxI" spacing="5" style=""><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 eNBSCn Box-s85n6m5-0 hkHKTC"><div id="ad" class="ad" data-ad-type="rect" data-dimensions="300x250" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Cleaner power is increasingly a priority for large businesses, particularly those in the tech sector. That sector's growth in and around Seattle has made the state a hub for invention while drawing droves of young, educated workers. Seattle-headquartered <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/the-report/articles/2019-03-15/elizabeth-warren-democrats-put-big-tech-in-the-2020-spotlight"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">Amazon dominates e-commerce and cloud computing globally</u></a>, while <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/cities/articles/2019-01-17/microsoft-pledges-500m-for-affordable-housing-in-seattle"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">a resurgent Microsoft</u></a> and rapidly expanding <a href="https://www.cbre.us/research-and-reports/us-life-sciences-clusters-2019" style="text-decoration:none;"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">life-sciences sector</u></a> that includes startup stars Adaptive Biotechnologies and Sana Biotechnologies are generating new technologies at a rapid clip.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Older corporate powerhouses founded or headquartered in the Seattle area – Starbucks, Costco, T-Mobile and Boeing – have been eclipsed by Amazon, whose recent growth remade Seattle's downtown core and recast its skyline. Washington’s gross domestic product growth rate – 5.7 percent in 2018, the highest in the nation – is largely thanks to that tech expansion, which has driven up real estate values.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>In the state, the tech sector's long-term annual growth rate tops 10 percent, said Chris Green, an assistant director in the state commerce department. But that measure actually undersells the tech boom's impact. </p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"The explosion in applications of machine learning, data analytics and automation has extended into all sectors, which has created an accelerating impact," Green said via email. </p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"Tech giants bring talent to the area," he continued. "Those with an entrepreneurial bent find a thriving startup ecosystem to support them."</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>It follows, then, that the state ranks highly – third in the nation – <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/rankings/economy">for economy</a> in U.S. News' latest Best States rankings. It also places No. 2 for infrastructure, No. 4 for health care and No. 4 for education. Washington's showing in these categories also helps it achieve the overall No. 1 ranking among states this year.</p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 gHribn s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP cApUxI" spacing="5" style=""><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 eNBSCn Box-s85n6m5-0 hkHKTC"><div id="ad" class="ad" data-ad-type="rect" data-dimensions="300x250" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div><div class="Box-s85n6m5-0 iktqLk" spacing="5"><a class="Anchor-u1fur6-0 eNYUZI" href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/slideshows/10-best-states-in-america" letter-spacing="0.6" prefix="\00ab\00a0"><div class="Box-s85n6m5-0 jqoQoo"><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP hQAyvA"><h3 class="sc-bdVaJa hcneNz" size="3" sizelarge="5" spacing="0" weight="7">U.S. News Ranks the Best States</h3></div><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP gtRwrM"><picture class="Image__Picture-afx55j-0 eVypoR"><img style="height: 493.922px; width: 752.656px; background: #000"></picture><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP ieRbAN"><button class="s1gfvgx7-0-Button-kDSBcD iKEclo" background="white" border="#aaaaaa"><div class="button-content"><svg role="img" class="s1sojkux-0-Icon-cxuQhR eJDnbY" rotate="0" fill="#ffffff"><filter id="dropshadow" x="15%" y="20%" height="80%" width="80%"><feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="2"></feGaussianBlur><feOffset dx="2" dy="1" result="offsetblur"></feOffset><feComponentTransfer><feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.25"></feFuncA></feComponentTransfer><feMerge><feMergeNode></feMergeNode><feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"></feMergeNode></feMerge></filter><use xlink:href="#image" filter="0"></use></svg>View All 12 Slides</div></button></div></div></div></a></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p><b>Infrastructure, Opportunity Challenges</b></p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>But despite the top 5 placements, each area shows deficiencies in access to high-quality systems: Washington lags in opportunity, ranking between Alaska and Kentucky at No. 19. And, while the state's infrastructure ranks second in the nation thanks to strengths in energy and internet access, its transportation system is middling and average commute times are among the longest in America.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Necessities, particularly housing, are beyond the means of many workers in booming areas of the state. An acute lack of affordable housing has been accompanied by yearslong waits for subsidized rentals in the Seattle area, where roadside greenbelts and sidewalks are packed with tents and shanties.</p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 cCSjAp s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP jMIcnN" data-ad-collide="true" spacing="5"><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP fHDDpG"><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 jaXlWV Box-s85n6m5-0 btRAdF"><div id="ad" class="ad lazy " data-ad-type="inart" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Growth has proven to be a mixed blessing, said Taylor Hoang, a Seattle-area restaurateur who founded the region's Ethnic Business Coalition.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"If I really look at the scale, I would say it tips a little more to the positive than the negative," Hoang said. "But civic leaders have a huge challenge and responsibility to make sure the scale doesn't tip the other way, and I think we're somewhat on the verge of that at the moment."</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>While it will remain a cornerstone employer for the region, Amazon has said it has no plans to expand inside Seattle's city limits. The city may well be full from Amazon's perspective, but <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/healthiest-communities/articles/2018-05-14/seattle-backs-tax-on-companies-like-amazon-to-help-homeless"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">a tiff in 2018 that saw Seattle City Hall pass</u></a> and then immediately withdraw a headcount-based tax on employers did nothing for relations between the company and city leaders.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p><b>A 'Leaky' College Pipeline</b></p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Regardless, Washington continues to train and draw young workers. State students are among the nation's best in eighth-grade reading and math test scores as measured by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, and come to their college degrees with less debt than most. </p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 gHribn s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP cApUxI" spacing="5" style=""><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 eNBSCn Box-s85n6m5-0 hkHKTC"><div id="ad" class="ad" data-ad-type="rect" data-dimensions="300x250" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>The state's universities, particularly the University of Washington, are both an educational force and an economic driver as Washington's innovation economy flourishes. Despite expansions in key initiatives like the UW's computer science department – a world-class program, expected to double in size in coming years – the state lags when it comes to converting high school graduates into college students.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>The state has "a leaky pipeline," said Paul Francis, executive director of the Council of Presidents, which coordinates efforts at Washington's six four-year public universities. </p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"We're losing students throughout the process," Francis said. "We've just got to do a better job of creating a college-going culture, otherwise you're going to see business and industry continue to import people from out of state. They're not able to meet their needs, because we're simply not growing our own."</p></div><div class="Box-s85n6m5-0 iktqLk" spacing="5"><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP jeHQht"><picture class="Image__Picture-afx55j-0 eVypoR"><img style="height: 502.016px; width: 752.656px; background: #000"></picture></div><p class="fqygwe-0-Paragraph-hHEPzZ eOtwoc" size="3" spacing="0"><span class="s14xcvr1-0-Raw-dZnnZd bRyDXB" fontcolor="#333333" size="3" spacing="0">The Seattle waterfront and downtown skyline are seen from the Bainbridge Island Ferry.</span><span class="Caption__CreditExposed-s1logqmf-0 fUuHFp Credit__SpanContainer-atr46r-0 lecYLZ s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP juwgkm"><span class="aabx0k-0-Span-juOiwt ldywyG" color="#666666" size="2"><svg role="img" class="s1sojkux-0-Icon-cxuQhR jnxwvW" rotate="0" fill="#666666"><filter id="dropshadow" x="15%" y="20%" height="80%" width="80%"><feGaussianBlur in="SourceAlpha" stdDeviation="2"></feGaussianBlur><feOffset dx="2" dy="1" result="offsetblur"></feOffset><feComponentTransfer><feFuncA type="linear" slope="0.25"></feFuncA></feComponentTransfer><feMerge><feMergeNode></feMergeNode><feMergeNode in="SourceGraphic"></feMergeNode></feMerge></filter><use xlink:href="#camera" filter="0"></use></svg>(George Rose/Getty Images)</span></span></p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p><b>An Economy Fueled by Energy and Invention</b></p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Venture capital is flowing more freely in the state, which once badly trailed <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/california">California's</a> Silicon Valley by that measure, and Washington now ranks No. 3 in patents granted per capita nationally thanks to inventors at Microsoft, Boeing and Amazon.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Washington's economy has long relied on cheap, reliably available hydroelectric power from dams on the Columbia River and elsewhere. Hydro fueled Boeing factories around Puget Sound during World War II and at the dawn of the jet age. It now spins servers and lights offices around the western United States.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>The state never depended on carbon-heavy electricity, and is in the process of shuttering its last coal-fired power plant. Washington utilities are stepping beyond the dams and boosting wind and solar capacities in the state, which currently ranks <a href="https://www.awea.org/resources/fact-sheets/state-facts-sheets" target="_blank"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">11th among the states in wind-generated electricity</u></a> and <a href="https://www.seia.org/states-map" target="_blank"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">30th in solar</u></a>, according to trade associations. The <a href="https://www.usnews.com/best-colleges/university-of-washington-3798">University of Washington</a> recently opened <a href="https://www.wcet.washington.edu/about/" target="_blank"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">a 15,000-square-foot shared "testbed" lab</u></a> meant to provide clean energy businesses with open access to state-of-the-art research and development tools. </p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 gHribn s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP cApUxI" spacing="5" style=""><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 eNBSCn Box-s85n6m5-0 hkHKTC"><div id="ad" class="ad" data-ad-type="rect" data-dimensions="300x250" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Access to renewable energy is a priority for corporate customers such as Walmart, Google, Microsoft and Amazon that have pledged to shrink their carbon footprint, said Lauren McCloy, senior energy policy adviser for energy with the governor's office. Washington-generated power is also among the cheapest in the nation, McCloy said, offering the state a competitive advantage when courting new industry or selling power out of state.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>For customers considering cleaner energy, McCloy said, "it's both an economic decision as well as a values-based decision."</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"In Washington, we're really uniquely positioned to lead on both of those data points," she continued. "We'll continue to be looking at resource diversity going forward, but we obviously want it all to be clean."</p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 cCSjAp s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP cApUxI" data-ad-collide="true" spacing="5"><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP kstgew"><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 jaXlWV Box-s85n6m5-0 kNkoGx"><div id="ad" class="ad lazy " data-ad-type="inart" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div></div><div class="s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP gYDkWa" spacing="4">[ <p class="AnchorBlock__KickerLine-ebdzwh-0 kGSXVo sc-bxivhb hgrABU" size="2" spacing="3" weight="7"><span class="Kicker__KickerSpan-s930mv6-0 dsOAje">SEE: </span></p><a class="Anchor-u1fur6-0 bRRClC" href="/news/best-states/slideshows/10-best-states-in-america" letter-spacing="0.6" prefix="\00ab\00a0">U.S. News Ranks the Best States</a> ]</div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Thanks to three large wind farms east of the Cascades, Puget Sound Energy, the state's largest power company, has become the nation's third-largest supplier of wind-generated electricity, said Ron Roberts, who directs power generation for the Bellevue-based utility. PSE, whose 1.1 million customers include Costco, has found a strong market for renewable, climate-friendly electricity. </p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>The utility now allows customers to buy into a pot of 100-percent local <a href="https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/rankings/infrastructure">renewable energy</a> through a 2-year-old program called Green Direct. PSE has opened up the program to new subscribers twice thus far, and Roberts said the energy inventory sold out swiftly both times.</p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 gHribn s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP cApUxI" spacing="5" style=""><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 eNBSCn Box-s85n6m5-0 hkHKTC"><div id="ad" class="ad" data-ad-type="rect" data-dimensions="300x250" data-targeting="{}" style=""></div></div></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"There's a pretty large appetite in the region for renewable energy," he said. "When we look at investments, we continue to look at investments that align with our customers' needs and wants and desires. Obviously, a carbon-neutral form of generation fits in to that."</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p><b>New Developments on the Horizon</b></p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>The state is also poised to lead in the development of electric grid modernization technologies. Intelligent, efficient electric grids allow intermittent energy generators like windmills to flourish. Two eastern Washington-based firms, Itron and Schweitzer Engineering Labs, are leaders in the field. Inventors elsewhere in the state hope to refine low-carbon biofuels that can power aircraft.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>Earlier this month, Washington lawmakers passed a suite of clean energy measures that put the state on a path to a fossil fuel-free electrical system by 2045. New programs shepherded through the state legislature by Inslee would also <a href="https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/clean-transportation-policy-brief-bill-signing.pdf" style="text-decoration:none;"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">dramatically expand access to electric vehicles</u></a>, <a href="https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/clean-buildings-policy-brief-bill-signing.pdf" style="text-decoration:none;"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">support and eventually mandate energy efficiency in large buildings</u></a>, and <a href="https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/hfc-policy-brief-bill-signing.pdf" style="text-decoration:none;"><u data-rte2-sanitize="underline">ban “super-pollutants”</u></a> that can do thousands of times more damage to the environment than carbon dioxide. </p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>In Inslee's view, Washington has shown that "cleaner is cheaper," and stronger. The clean energy sector, by his reckoning, is growing twice as fast as the rest of the regional economy, and creating opportunities in areas far from coastal tech centers.</p></div><div class="Raw-s14xcvr1-0 AXWJq" size="5" spacing="4"><p>"We're as confident as ever," the governor said, "about our efforts to speed the transition to clean energy."<br></p></div><div class="Hide-s18sxv0v-0 gHribn s85n6m5-0-Box-cwadsP cApUxI" spacing="5" style=""><div class="Ad__Container-cohcnl-0 eNBSCn Box-s85n6m5-0 hkHKTC"><div id="ad" class="ad" data-ad-type="rect"
